block.p: For those of us living in countries that are contemplating joining the euro, the currency's performance is ominous (''Decline of the Euro,'' editorial, April 29). The euro's decline is a reflection of the structural weaknesses of Continental economies (extremely high taxation, inflexible labor markets, protectionist trade policies) that will continue to inhibit euro-zone economic growth.

For those of us living in countries that are contemplating joining the euro, the currency's performance is ominous (''Decline of the Euro,'' editorial, April 29). The euro's decline is a reflection of the structural weaknesses of Continental economies (extremely high taxation, inflexible labor markets, protectionist trade policies) that will continue to inhibit euro-zone economic growth.

The euro is a solid currency, but it is not dynamic, for although the countries that use it are wealthy and happy, they are also expensive and inefficient compared with Britain and inert compared with the United States.
J. EVERETT BOATRIGHT St. Andrews, Scotland, April 29, 2000
